India vs Pakistan: What the Advertisers Told Us About Consumer Sentiment The game yesterday wasn‚Äôt just about cricket‚Äîit was a snapshot of where brands think India is heading, and it raised some interesting questions about consumer sentiment. You had the traditional big boys‚ÄîAramco, DP World, and Emirates‚Äîinvesting in long-term brand equity. No surprises there. But then, there were some curveballs. Livebhagwan advertising during the match was a bold move, likely riding the Kumbh Mela wave. While it signals a growing trend in spirituality, I‚Äôm not fully convinced it indicates increased discretionary spending on live poojas. Hotstar also advertised their Maha Shivratri special, showing that spirituality is becoming mainstream. We saw some return from the Crypto trading platforms. Irrationality is creeping back in Dream11, as expected, continues to drive revenue through cricket betting. Groww went big, promoting its India‚Äôs No. 1 stockbroker claim. ICICI Bank‚Äôs sharp ads and the classic Mutual Fund Sahi Hai campaign with Sachin, Dhoni, and Rohit show a clear bet on Indians investing more. Visa also advertised with Vicky Kaushal, pushing a premium product to a mass audience, signaling optimism. FMCG was not as visible‚Äîbarring Coke and Domino‚Äôs. That‚Äôs telling. It hints that FMCG is playing it safe, maybe post a rough patch. QComm was not as visible. Perhaps post IPO rationality is in. We did see Vimal Zubaan Kesari on repeat. Then there were the outliers.A tiles player going all out on marketing? Interesting Shows a new category developing.Roff was watching this closely. Auto ancillaries like CEAT Tyres were consistent with cricket ads, but the creative felt flat‚Äîare they maximizing their media spend? Mobil1 featured Hrithik Roshan, and Castrol signed SRK. With more cars on the road, the premiumization of the Indian consumer is clear. So, what does this all mean? There‚Äôs a growing bet on discretionary spends - but its a lot more tempered than we have seen in the past. Financial services are banking on consumer optimism. Optimism in investment in stocks and mutual funds as an asset class. FMCG is cautious‚Äîmaybe waiting for clearer signs of growth. Startups and newer players are getting bold again, signaling loosened cash flows. The spiritual sector was an interesting anomaly, and the return of crypto highlights the growing mood of irrationality in investing. It felt like an 80-20 split: 20% of ads seemed like burn, 80% were solid, long-term plays.
